channel.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
channel.description:
I am Colt on RSBot and I do know java and have written a few scripts. I wrote a runescape loader that loads both signed and unsigned versions of runescape. Now I want to know how to find the correct hooks in the obfuscated client. My theory is that I can load up all the fields in the runescape applet and print their name and value repeatedly and search for the value of the hook I want. Is there a way to do this and is it practical? Or is there a better way. If someone would suggest de-obfuscating the client, I am totally clueless on how one would do that. 400 a's, b's, and pb.ac's are quite confusing.
I also tried using jdb, but it is really annoying because it works almost nothing like the gnu gdb and is very non-standard and the help is disorganized. Is gdb the key to cracking runescape? I also have another theory that I can search for 100 in iHaxGames (It's like cheat engine) so that I can find the address of the run energy field and then trace back through java to find where that memory was declared in the class files.
As you can see, I am either close or totally clueless. Help appreciated.

item.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

[quote=“RSBColt, post:5, topic:327948”]I have mac. Unlimited terminal space. I tried it once in jdb.
With the updater thing, would getting the number of fields and methods and then the method return types and parameters work?[/quote]
WIN

Read full topic

i am posting in this thread to inform you that i did not read this thread because you said “i am smart”

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“RSBColt, post:8, topic:327948”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=424333.msg3116308#msg3116308 date=1265002156]
basing your entire search for the identification of certain fields on field monitoring during client runtime is highly impractical

if you know java as well as you claim, then simply decompile the client and read through the code to determine the actual use of each field. i would suggest using a deobfuscated client in order to be able to prove your assumptions regarding the use of certain fields through code modification (since you would be able to successfully recompile the client)

there are a few publicly released deobfuscators; run one on the current client and use that

it would be useless to start a search for a pattern to identify a specific field with no background information on it, look through updater outputs in order to know which field in the client pertains to the field you are looking for so you can later proceed to identify a pattern which you will later be able to use in your updater

ps if you lack the competence required to do any of the things suggested above, you are clearly not apt to proceed with this project of yours
[/quote]

I guess I should have started ages ago when runescape was still simple? It sounds like it would take months for me to identify fields and to be able to de-obfuscate the client, I need to have an extremely-adept knowledge of how the client works? Well, I’ll look into the de-obfuscator thing.[/quote]do as i said you idiot, and the identification of a certain pattern for a specific field shouldnt take over 10 minutes

deobfuscate the client using a publicly released deobfuscator, search some current updater logs for the field you are looking for in order to know which field it pertains to in the client and find a pattern

it is obvious you have no fucking clue as to what you are on about, so i suggest quitting the attempt

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

RSBColt:

[quote=Tenen]Mentioning you’re from RSBot is asking for a spank. And no, you do not know Java.

Something wrong with RSBot?[/quote]
yeah, the retarded dumb shits

I have mac. Unlimited terminal space. I tried it once in jdb. With the updater thing, would getting the number of fields and methods and then the method return types and parameters work?
?? no... you want to make your updater strong, so you want to find a pattern that will possibly ALWAYS stay constant, such as [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,419463.0.html]NPC debug[/url]

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
item.dc:creator: @RSBColt RSBColt
item.description:
@RSBColt wrote:

Mentioning you're from RSBot is asking for a spank. And no, you do not know Java.
Something wrong with RSBot? And, I do know java. C++ too.
l2dividebyzero
? It works try it out.
Although you could do this, there is so many fields, Command Prompt wouldn't even have enough space. It is also impractical because fields change name and positions from update to update.

The practical way is to write an “updater.” This updater would use a bytecode library (preferably ObjectWeb’s ASM or BCEL) to open up the .class structure (a.k.a. bytecode) of RuneScape’s classes. Then, it would look for patterns that stay consistent on each update to locate certain fields (e.g., maybe the energy field is multiplied by 20, divided by 5, and then printed to output).


I have mac. Unlimited terminal space. I tried it once in jdb.
With the updater thing, would getting the number of fields and methods and then the method return types and parameters work?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflection Help (I am smart)
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

RSBColt:

I am Colt on RSBot and I do know java and have written a few scripts.

Mentioning you’re from RSBot is asking for a spank. And no, you do not know Java.

RSBColt:

I wrote a runescape loader that loads both signed and unsigned versions of runescape.

l2dividebyzero

RSBColt:

My theory is that I can load up all the fields in the runescape applet and print their name and value repeatedly and search for the value of the hook I want. Is there a way to do this and is it practical?

Although you could do this, there is so many fields, Command Prompt wouldn’t even have enough space. It is also impractical because fields change name and positions from update to update.

The practical way is to write an “updater.” This updater would use a bytecode library (preferably ObjectWeb’s ASM or BCEL) to open up the .class structure (a.k.a. bytecode) of RuneScape’s classes. Then, it would look for patterns that stay consistent on each update to locate certain fields (e.g., maybe the energy field is multiplied by 20, divided by 5, and then printed to output).

see:
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,293125.0.html - introduction to bytecode stuff (see this first)
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,293071.0.html - how to inject stuff into the client
http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,288851.0.html - updater (doesn’t work but shows concept)

Read full topic
